bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Fred W. Rankin, April 22, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg assures Rankin that Cornwell will make the suggested corrections to the McDowell painting. He is pleased that Rankin may be able to speak at the unveiling of the painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Fred W. Rankin, April 22, 1942
div1.opener:
April 22, 1942.
Col. Fred W. Rankin, M.C.
The Office of the Surgeon
General of the
U. S. Army
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Rankin,
div1.p:
Your letter of April 20 is most welcome.
I took up your suggestions for changes in the painting with Mr.
Cornwell, and after talking with him on the 'phone this morning
I am sure that he can take care of the points that you have men-
tioned in a short time.

We are certainly pleased that you think you
will be able to be present at the unveiling on Monday noon, June
8th. On the basis of our experience of last year we feel con-
fident that there will be a large group at the luncheon who will
be much interested in anything you have to say on the subject of
McDowell or war surgery. As a matter of fact, we expect that
a large percentage of the members of the House of Delegates will
attend the luncheon which is to be in the Rose Room of the Hotel
Traymore.

As soon as Mr. Cornwell has completed the
changes in the painting we will send you a new photograph.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, George A. Kellogg GAK:L
cc. to D.J. Withington
Dr. Hench
Mr. Frank Law
